qas.question: What socioeconomic class was associated with the lounge bar in the 20th century?
What economic class was most likely to be found in the tap room?
In pence, what did the cheapest beer cost in the four-ale bar?
What was the tap room sawdust meant to absorb spills and spit called?
What is another name for the lounge bar?

context: By the 20th century, the <a4_0>saloon<a4_0/>, or lounge bar, had become a <a0_0>middle-class<a0_0/> room[citation needed]—carpets on the floor, cushions on the seats, and a penny or two on the prices,[citation needed] while the public bar, or tap room, remained <a1_0>working class<a1_0/> with bare boards, sometimes with sawdust to absorb the spitting and spillages (known as "<a3_0>spit and sawdust<a3_0/>"), hard bench seats, and cheap beer[citation needed]. This bar was known as the four-ale bar from the days when the cheapest beer served there cost <a2_0>4<a2_0/> pence (4d) a quart.[citation needed]
